title: High Arable Land Per Capita
description: In 2021, Kazakhstan had 1.50 hectares of arable land per person, one of the highest ratios globally, indicating significant agricultural potential.

title: Minimal Urban Slum Population
description: As of 2020, only 0.79% of Kazakhstan's urban population lived in slums, showcasing effective urban planning and housing policies.

title: High Export Tax Revenue
description: In 2023, Kazakhstan collected 2,135,352,265,935.25 local currency units from export taxes, reflecting a robust export sector.

title: Perfect Male Primary Education Completion
description: In 2019, 100% of male students in Kazakhstan persisted to the last grade of primary school, indicating strong educational retention.

title: High Female Post-Secondary Education Attainment
description: By 2018, 79.04% of women aged 25+ had completed post-secondary education, highlighting gender equality in education.

title: High Secondary School Enrollment
description: Kazakhstan achieved a 99.84% net enrollment rate in secondary education in 2019, reflecting widespread access to education.

title: Extensive Rural Handwashing Facilities
description: In 2019, 98.73% of Kazakhstan's rural population had access to basic handwashing facilities, promoting public health.

title: Low Poverty Rate
description: In 2021, only 3.1% of Kazakhstan's population lived below 50% of the median income, indicating a relatively low poverty level.

title: High Employment Rates
description: By 2022, Kazakhstan had employment rates of 94.5% for females and 95.7% for males, showcasing a strong labor market.

title: Low Severe Food Insecurity
description: In 2022, only 0.6% of Kazakhstan's population experienced severe food insecurity, reflecting effective food security measures.

title: Low Government Expenditure on Primary Education
description: In 2018, only 23.51% of GDP per capita was spent on primary education per student, suggesting potential underinvestment.

title: Low Expenditure on Primary Education
description: In 2018, only 65.78% of government education expenditure was allocated to primary education, indicating possible budgetary constraints.
